item.title: Apex
item.description:
Description

Apex is an open-source PyTorch extension that helps users maximize deep learning training performance on NVIDIA GPUs. Mixed precision utilities in Apex are designed to improve training speed while maintaining the accuracy and stability of training in single precision. Learn more in this talk.
item.dc:creator: Michael Carilli

item.title: Collaborative Natural Language Inference
item.description:
Description

Get an overview from Professor Sasha Rush of Cornell on the latest research in collaborative natural language inference.
item.dc:creator: Sasha Rush

item.title: CrypTen
item.description:
Description

Practical applications of ML via cloud-based or machine-learning-as-a-service (MLaaS) platforms pose a range of security and privacy challenges. In particular, users of these platforms may not want or be able to share unencrypted data, which prevents them from taking full advantage of ML tools. CrypTen is a new community-based research platform for taking the field of privacy-preserving ML forward.
item.dc:creator: Laurens van der Maaten

item.title: Dataloader Design for PyTorch
item.description:
Description

Learn about the PyTorch data loading pipeline and components - the dataset, the sampler, and the dataloader.
item.dc:creator: Tongzhou Wang

item.title: Detectron2 - Next Gen Object Detection Library
item.description:
Description

Object detection and segmentation are used for tasks ranging from autonomous vehicles to content understanding for platform integrity. Learn about Detectron2, an object detection library now implemented in PyTorch. Detectron2 provides support for the latest models and tasks, increased flexibility to aid computer vision research, and improvements in maintainability and scalability to support production use cases.
item.dc:creator: Yuxin Wu

item.title: Keynote
item.description:
Description

PyTorch has become a popular open source machine learning framework for cutting edge research, and is increasingly being used in production. Watch Mike Schroepfer, Chief Technology Officer at Facebook, open the keynote at the second annual PyTorch Developer Conference.
item.dc:creator: Mike Schroepfer

item.title: Linear Algebra in PyTorch
item.description:
Description

PyTorch 1.2 and 1.3 have added several enhancements for linear algebra in PyTorch, including native batching support, support for gradients, and new semantic naming schemes. Learn more in this session.
item.dc:creator: Vishwak Srinivasan

item.title: Panel Discussion
item.description:
Description

Hear from users and creators in the PyTorch community as they discuss their needs and thoughts around ML tooling, open source ecosystems, and more. This panel is moderated by Soumith Chintala, and includes Lisha Li from Rosebud, Michela Paganini from Facebook, Clément Delangue from HuggingFace, Rachel Thomas from fast.ai, Maria Popova from UNC.
item.dc:creator: Soumith Chintala

item.title: Privacy Preserving AI
item.description:
Description

Learn the basics of secure and private AI techniques, including federated learning and secure multi-party computation. In this talk, Andrew Trask of OpenMined highlights the importance of privacy preserving machine learning, and how to use privacy-focused tools like PySyft.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Trask

item.title: PyTorch at Dolby Labs
item.description:
Description

Hear how Dolby Labs is using PyTorch to develop deep learning for audio, and learn about the challenges that audio AI presents and the breakthroughs and applications they’ve built at Dolby to push the field forward.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Kumar

item.title: PyTorch at Microsoft
item.description:
Description

PyTorch is becoming the deep learning tool of choice inside Microsoft. Learn how it’s being used to improve existing features and enable new capabilities in products such as Bing, Outlook, Powerpoint Designer, and more.
item.dc:creator: Saurabh Tiwary

item.title: PyTorch at Tesla
item.description:
Description

Hear from Andrej Karpathy on how Tesla is using PyTorch to develop full self-driving capabilities for its vehicles, including AutoPilot and Smart Summon.
item.dc:creator: Andrej Karpathy

item.title: PyTorch at Uber
item.description:
Description

In this talk, Sidney Zhang from Uber talks about how Uber ATG uses PyTorch, and specific features including TorchScript, to develop and deploy cutting-edge deep learning models to power self-driving cars.
item.dc:creator: Sidney Zhang

item.title: PyTorch Front-End Features: Named Tensors and Type Promotion
item.description:
Description

Cornell University’s Sasha Rush has argued that, despite its ubiquity in deep learning, the traditional implementation of tensors has significant shortcomings, such as exposing private dimensions, broadcasting based on absolute position, and keeping type information in documentation. He proposed named tensors as an alternative approach. PyTorch now supports the ability to name tensors, allowing for clearer code with less need for inline comments.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Chanan

item.title: PyTorch in Robotics
item.description:
Description

Learn about the research work at Caltech focused on risk aware machine learning for dynamic robotics control, and how PyTorch is being used to build deep learning systems for projects like the neural lander.
item.dc:creator: Yisong Yue

item.title: PyTorch Mobile
item.description:
Description

Running ML on edge devices is growing in importance as applications continue to demand lower latency. It is also a foundational element for privacy-preserving techniques such as federated learning. To enable more efficient on-device ML, PyTorch 1.3 now supports an end-to-end workflow from Python to deployment on iOS and Android. Learn more about this early, experimental release.
item.dc:creator: David Reiss

item.title: PyTorch on Google Cloud TPUs
item.description:
Description

Google Cloud TPU support in PyTorch is now broadly available. Hear how engineers from Facebook, Google, and Salesforce worked together to enable and pilot Google Cloud TPU support in PyTorch, including experimental support for Cloud TPU Pods.
item.dc:creator: Vishal Mishra
item.category: Google Cloud TPU Support in PyTorch

item.title: PyTorch ONNX Export Support
item.description:
Description

The PyTorch ONNX exporter allows trained models to be easily exported to the ONNX model format. Learn about the latest updates including increased model coverage, improved performance, and support for multiple ONNX opset versions for multiple backends.
item.dc:creator: Lara Haidar

item.title: PyTorch Summer Hackathon Winners
item.description:
Description

The in-person and online Global PyTorch Summer Hackathon brought together researchers and developers around the world to build innovative new projects with PyTorch. Developers submitted creative projects ranging from livestock disease detection to AI-powered financial assistants.
item.dc:creator: Joe Spisak

item.title: Quantization
item.description:
Description

It’s important to make efficient use of both server-side and on-device compute resources when developing ML applications. To support more efficient deployment on servers and edge devices, PyTorch 1.3 now supports 8-bit model quantization using the familiar eager mode Python API.
item.dc:creator: Dmytro Dzhulgakov

item.title: Research to Production: PyTorch JIT/TorchScript Updates
item.description:
Description

TorchScript allows developers to create serializable and optimizable models from PyTorch code. Any TorchScript program can be saved from a Python process and loaded in a process where there is no Python dependency. Using TorchScript and the PyTorch JIT compiler, organizations and businesses have been able to use PyTorch not just for state-of-the-art research, but also to more easily take their trained models to production.
item.dc:creator: Michael Suo

item.title: Sotabench for Reproducible Research
item.description:
Description

Papers with Code recently launched Sotabench, a free and open website created to benchmark and rate the performance of state-of-the-art open source models from GitHub. Learn more about this new resource for reproducible research.
item.dc:creator: Robert Stojnic

item.title: Speech Extensions to Fairseq
item.description:
Description

Language translation and audio processing are critical components in systems and applications such as search, translation, speech, and assistants. Fairseq, a framework for sequence-to-sequence applications such as language translation, has been extended to include support for end-to-end learning for speech and audio recognition tasks. These extensions enable faster exploration and prototyping of new speech research ideas while offering a clear path to production.
item.dc:creator: Dmytro Okhonko

item.title: StanfordNLP
item.description:
Description

StanfordNLP is a new Python natural language processing analysis package built on PyTorch that’s designed to process many human languages. Learn more about the StanfordNLP library in this talk.
item.dc:creator: Yuhao Zhang

item.title: What's new in PyTorch 1.3
item.description:
Description

Get an overview of the latest updates in PyTorch 1.3. This release includes new experimental features and capabilities including the ability to name tensors, seamless model deployment to mobile devices, quantization, and more.
item.dc:creator: Lin Qiao
